<div class="courses-listing">

<h2>2017 Spring
</h2>










		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-978" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/the-baroque-genealogy-and-topography/" rel="bookmark">Comp Lit 215: The Baroque: Genealogy and Topography</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Timothy Hampton </i></p>

			<p class="entry">Baroque culture is the first instance in the West of a "global" cultural movement. It also offers the first example of an artistic moment that is truly interdisciplinary. In this seminar we will study the emergence and development of Baroque literature and thought, beginning at the end of the sixteenth century, from Rome to Mexico. Our approach will have two aspects. On the one hand, we will want to identify and study certain key features of Baroque culture, across languages, continents, and media, working out, as it were, a kind of topography of culture and politics. We will focus on such themes as the theatricalization of power, the role of allegory, the question of a Baroque "style," imperial and urban experience, and the intersection of arts and disciplines. At the same time, however, we will be interested in the curious history of the "Baroque" in modern critical thought, from the appearance of the term in Art Historical writing at the end of the 19th century (Wöfflin, Burkhardt), through the various nationalist Baroques of the mid-twentieth, the neo-Baroque of certain post-War novelists (Carpentier, Simon), to the critical redemption of Baroque culture for our own moment by the work of Walter Benjamin and Gilles Deleuze. <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/the-baroque-genealogy-and-topography/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-980" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/english-renaissance/" rel="bookmark">English 246C: English Renaissance</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor David Marno </i></p>

			<p class="entry">In this survey, we follow how authors from Francesco Petrarca and Thomas More to John Donne participated in the grand cultural project of the Renaissance, ostensibly defined by the belief that consuming and producing culture would elevate human beings above their natural state. Many of our authors supported the project; some opposed it fervently. But willingly or not, everyone we read during the semester contributed to it, if only by virtue of recording their impressions, thoughts, feelings, and fancies in writing. In addition to the works of Petrarca, Wyatt, Philip and Mary Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, and Donne, among others, we will also explore how scholarly views about the Renaissance as a cultural project have changed and developed from Jacob Burckhardt’s The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy to New Historicism and beyond. <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/english-renaissance/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-982" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/idols-and-ideology/" rel="bookmark">English 250 : Idols and Ideology</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Vicki Kahn </i></p>

			<p class="entry">The history of Western literary theory is often told in terms of the concept of mimesis. But there is another, equally powerful, anti-mimetic strand to this history, and that is the critique of mimesis as a form of idolatry. In this course, we will explore this critique from the prohibition against images in the Hebrew bible up through modern attacks on mimesis as inherently ideological. Our main literary texts in the first half of the semester will be taken from Reformation England, when there was a fierce debate about the harmful power of images and the necessity of iconoclasm. We will focus on works by Calvin, Luther, Marlowe, Bacon, Shakespeare, and Milton. In the second half of the semester, we will discuss the afterlife of iconoclasm in Marx, Freud, Althusser, Zizek, Adorno, Terry Eagleton, and Isobel Armstrong. Students whose interests lie primarily in national literatures other than English are welcome, and may write their final papers on primary texts and literatures not discussed in class, though they must engage the theoretical texts assigned for the seminar. <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/idols-and-ideology/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-984" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/spirituality-literature-and-politics-in-early-modern-france-1550-1750/" rel="bookmark">French 245B: Spirituality, Literature and Politics in Early Modern France (1550-1750)</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Déborah Blocker </i></p>

			<p class="entry">In 1598, the Edict of Nantes puts an end to France’s wars of religion. In its wake, Catholicism is revivified, via the founding of a number of Counter-Reformation orders and movements, all competing to rekindle the Catholic faith. These attempts to re-evangelize France hinged on preaching, but were also increasingly dependent on printed works. They were aimed at a lay and even mundane readership, which was increasingly avid of literary works, such as plays, short stories and novels. This seminar examines how Counter-Reformation evangelism shaped France’s emerging literary market, studying how spirituality and literature were thereby configured as separate yet tightly connected practices.  <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/spirituality-literature-and-politics-in-early-modern-france-1550-1750/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-986" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/early-modern-europe/" rel="bookmark">History 275B : Early Modern Europe</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ethan Shagan </i></p>

			<p class="entry">History 275 is the foundational course for graduate students in the history of early modern Europe from the Renaissance to the French Revolution.  This year, rather than surveying disconnected subjects, I have decided to organize the syllabus around the theme “Forms and Functions of Early Modern Politics.” This is capacious enough to include a wide range of interconnected topics: state formation; empire; gender and power; popular politics; the general crisis of the seventeenth century; political culture; church-state relations; and much else besides.  Readings will consist of secondary scholarship covering many different parts of (mostly Western) Europe from the fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries, supplemented by primary sources in political theory from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment. <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/early-modern-europe/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-988" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/ornament-and-alterity/" rel="bookmark">History of Art 270: Ornament and Alterity</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Todd Olson </i></p>

			<p class="entry">This seminar will explore the early modern origins of three closely interrelated stylistic categories, the Gothic, grotesque, and arabesque, and the ways in which they engage with the perceived alterity of ornament.  Both the Gothic and grotesque were defined in terms of bodily deformity, femininity, perverse hybridity, and lack of regulation and control, and used to characterize the foreignness of the arabesque, and vice versa.  This course will interrogate the anxieties (and perhaps latent desires) underlying the formation and perception of these categories, including xenophobia, misogyny, and fear of the irrational and exotic.  We will closely examine illustrated books, prints, and buildings of the early modern world (e.g. France, Italy, colonial Latin America, South Asia).  The seminar will draw from other fields (such as anthropology and ethnomathematics) to consider the persistence of these categories in the uncontrollable reproduction and dissemination of ornament. <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/ornament-and-alterity/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-990" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/shakespeares-italy-books-and-readers-in-the-anglo-italian-renaissance/" rel="bookmark">Italian Studies 204: Shakespeare’s Italy: Books and Readers in the Anglo-Italian Renaissance</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Diego Pirillo </i></p>

			<p class="entry">‘Inglese italianato è un diavolo incarnato’ (an Italianate Englishman is a devil incarnate), Roger Ascham famously said in the Schoolmaster (1570), blaming the ‘Italianate Englishmen’ for spending their time reading Petrarch and Machiavelli rather than the Bible. Despite Ascham’s attack on the ‘Italianate Englishmen’, the influence of Renaissance Italy in early modern England remained wide and persistent, as is clear to any reader of the Merchant of Venice or Romeo and Juliet. This seminar will not simply look at Shakespeare’s Italian sources but will investigate more broadly the Tudor and Stuart encounter with Renaissance Italy, examining its cultural, religious and political implications. Special attention will be given not only to canonical authors (Shake-speare, Sidney, Bacon, Machiavelli, Castiglione, Ariosto, Bruno, Montaigne and others) but also to the system through which books were disseminated and received, bringing to light the crucial role played by publishers, translators, readers, censors and other cultural go-betweens. The entire seminar will be hosted by the Bancroft Library and will give students the opportunity to access its collections and to learn new methodologies for the study of books as material objects. <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/shakespeares-italy-books-and-readers-in-the-anglo-italian-renaissance/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>

		<div class="post">

			<h3 id="post-992" class="person"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/christianity-and-capitalism/" rel="bookmark">Spanish 280: Christianity and Capitalism</a></h3>

			<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ivonne del Valle </i></p>

			<p class="entry">According to Max Weber the spirit of Protestantism made possible the emergence of capitalism proper. In his recounting, Spain’s imperial/colonial experience could be bracketed as a previous and/or different moment, what Marx termed primitive accumulation. Without negating that the 16th and 17th centuries in the Americas (one of the central vantage points of the course) could be rightfully considered in such a way, we will study how religion and economy intermingled, clashed, and related to each other in an enterprise in which they were the central, directing forces (evangelization/exploitation of people and resources).

Focusing on Spain’s Catholic version of the economy we will investigate violence and its justification, religious metaphors and ideology, as well as the processes of rationalization and discipline, ordering that accompanied the expansion of Christianity, in order to understand the particular forms the economy took under early modern/colonial Catholicism and the cultural, social forms that accompanied it.  
 <i><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/christianity-and-capitalism/" rel="bookmark">[more]</a></i></p>
			

		</div>
</div> 

</div id="content">


</div>

<div class="courses-listing">

<h2>Courses of Interest
</h2>




	<p>These courses may be of interest to students in Renaissance and Early Modern Studies; however, they will not count toward the DE.</p>







</div>

<div id="header" class="content courses">
		<h1><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/">Renaissance &amp; Early Modern Studies</a></h1>
		<div class="description"></div>
</div>
<div id="nav" class="content" role="navigation">
		<div class="menu-main-navigation-courses-container"><ul id="menu-main-navigation-courses" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1133" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-1133"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2018-spring/">Courses</a></li>

	<div class="content">

<h2>Current Courses</h2>
<ul class="courses-list">
					<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/las-colonias-y-el-fundamento-del-mundo-moderno-spanish-280-section-2/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to LAS COLONIAS Y EL FUNDAMENTO DEL MUNDO MODERNO">LAS COLONIAS Y EL FUNDAMENTO DEL MUNDO MODERNO</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/measure-for-measure-investigating-histories-of-metrology-and-modernity-rhetoric-230/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to MEASURE FOR MEASURE: INVESTIGATING HISTORIES OF METROLOGY AND MODERNITY">MEASURE FOR MEASURE: INVESTIGATING HISTORIES OF METROLOGY AND MODERNITY</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/latin-literature-of-the-renaissance-neo-latin-latin-140/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to LATIN LITERATURE OF THE RENAISSANCE (NEO-LATIN)">LATIN LITERATURE OF THE RENAISSANCE (NEO-LATIN)</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/heterodoxy-orthodoxy-and-early-modern-religion-history-280b/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to HETERODOXY, ORTHODOXY, AND EARLY MODERN RELIGION">HETERODOXY, ORTHODOXY, AND EARLY MODERN RELIGION</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/early-modern-europe-history-275b/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to EARLY MODERN EUROPE">EARLY MODERN EUROPE</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/french-society-and-the-old-regime-1600-1800-french-245a/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to FRENCH SOCIETY AND THE OLD REGIME (1600-1800)">FRENCH SOCIETY AND THE OLD REGIME (1600-1800)</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/introduction-to-renaissance-humanism-comparative-literature-215/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to INTRODUCTION TO RENAISSANCE HUMANISM">INTRODUCTION TO RENAISSANCE HUMANISM</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/graduate-seminar-renaissance-jusepe-de-ribera-history-of-art-260/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to Graduate Seminar (Renaissance): Jusepe de Ribera (1591-1652)">Graduate Seminar (Renaissance): Jusepe de Ribera (1591-1652)</a></li>

		
</ul>

<h2>Upcoming Courses</h2>
<ul class="courses-list">
					<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/moliere-stage-page-patronage-french-230a/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to Molière:  Stage, Page, Patronage">Molière:  Stage, Page, Patronage</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/the-circulation-of-the-written-word-in-early-modern-france-and-italy-1450-1800-french-245a/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to The Circulation Of the Written Word In Early Modern France and Italy (1450-1800)">The Circulation Of the Written Word In Early Modern France and Italy (1450-1800)</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/the-sacred-images-texts-theories-german-205-comparative-literature-212-history-of-art-258/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to The Sacred: Images, Texts, Theories">The Sacred: Images, Texts, Theories</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/mass-entertainment-in-renaissance-london-and-golden-age-hollywood-english-250-section-2/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to Mass Entertainment in Renaissance London and Golden-Age Hollywood">Mass Entertainment in Renaissance London and Golden-Age Hollywood</a></li>

		<li><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses/shakespeare-english-217/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a></li>

		
</ul>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-747 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-fall" id="post-747">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Italian Studies 215 : Ariostan Histories: From Romance to Epic to Novel</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Albert R. Ascoli </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>Our aim will be to situate Ludovico Ariosto’s <em>Orlando furioso</em>, the most widely read literary text of the sixteenth century, at a pivotal place within an array of literary, cultural, and socio-political histories. Most prominently, from a literary-historical point of view, the <em>Furioso </em>may be situated within two genealogies that are often read in opposition to one another: the Renaissance recuperation of classical epic poetry in the Virgilian (and Homeric) mode through a filter of chivalric romance (culminating in Tasso and Milton), and the early modern passage from romance, novella, and other late medieval genres to what would become <em>the </em>literary genre par excellence in centuries to come, the novel (the first great exemplars being Rabelais’ <em>Gargantua and Pantagruel </em>and Cervantes’ <em>Don Quixote</em>). The course will begin with a survey of classical, late medieval and early Renaissance precursors of the <em>Furioso </em>(most notably the <em>Aeneid </em>and Boiardo’s <em>Innamoramento di Orlando</em>) and conclude with some weeks dedicated to genealogical aftermath of the <em>Furioso</em>, above all in Tasso’s <em>Gerusalemme Liberata</em>. The “body” of the course will, needless to say, be dedicated to a close study of the <em>Furioso </em>itself.</p>
<p>Students are expected to attend and participate regularly. There will be occasional in-class presentations and some shorter writing assignments. The principal assignment for the course is a research paper of ca. 6000 words (ca. 25 pages). Topics must be closely related to the concerns of the course although they may focus on authors and texts not directly treated in seminar (whether from Italy or another national/linguistic tradition). Students enrolled for two credits will not write a final essay, but will complete all other course assignments, plus two shorter papers (ca. 5 pages) over the course of the semester.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=FL&x=66&p_ccn=47107&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=Italian+Studies&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=9">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

<li id="menu-item-657" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-657"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2014-fall/">Fall 2014</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-290"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2012-fall/">Fall 2012</a></li>
</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>
</ul></div></div>
	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-649 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-spring" id="post-649">

			<h2 class="single-course">	French 245A and Italian 215: Authors, Readers and Censors in Early Modern Europe: From the Printing of Books to the Management of Information (1450-1800)</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professors Déborah Blocker and Diego Pirillo </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the Critical Approaches and Methodology requirement for the DE in REMS.  It may also count as an elective.<br />
</em></p>
<p>This seminar introduces students to the fundamentals of book history (the invention of the printing press, the material forms of the book, and the development and control of the book market), but also to what in the field is now called scribal culture, that is the continued circulation of manuscripts during the age of the printing press and, more generally, the lasting and constant competition between books and manuscripts in the high culture of early modern Europe. The class mainly investigates the development of the book and manuscript markets in light of the larger question of how the Renaissance and the early modern period came to terms with the ‘overload of information’ that marked the early age of print, adopting new strategies to gather, store and appropriate knowledge. Particular attention will be dedicated to examining how information (mundane, political, literary and artistic, scientific, etc.) was produced and circulated, the guises under which it travelled, the ways in which it was policed and how it was received.</p>
<p>This seminar also has a practical purpose, which is to make students more capable of finding, describing, and adequately using the print and manuscript sources they will need to study in the context of their dissertations. All classes take place in the Bancroft Library and students will be exposed to a variety of rare materials during most sessions of the seminar. We also learn how to analyze and describe rare these documents (bibliographical description) and we discuss how libraries and archives developed and are currently organized when it comes to early modern materials. Finally, the course addresses the question of the growing availability of early modern print and manuscript sources over the internet, both investigating how they can be located and discussing the drawbacks of studying such materials in immaterial formats.</p>
<p>This course will be useful both to students of literature (in French, Italian, English, Spanish and Portuguese or German, as many of the fundamentals of book and information history are similar across Europe) and to historians in general. Historians of art, music and philosophy will also find the course of interest, given how important rare books and manuscripts sources now are for these fields as well.</p>
<p>The course deals with Europe as a whole and is taught entirely in English and, but many of the rare books and manuscripts studied are in French or in Italian, because of the instructors’ current specializations. For those students wishing to do the assigned bibliography exercises on either French or Italian materials a reasonable reading knowledge of French and/or Italian is needed. For those students possessing reading knowledge neither of French nor of Italian, alternative bibliography exercises in either English, German, Hebrew, Latin and/or Ancient Greek can be set up, in consultation with the instructors. All students will however be required to read all secondary readings in the English language, even when mostly French and/or Italian materials are discussed therein.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=SP&p_ccn=32497&x=0&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=0">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-382 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2013-fall" id="post-382">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Spanish 280, section 2: Barroco</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ivonne del Valle </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><i>This course fulfills the Intellectual History requirement for the DE in REMS.  It may also count as an elective.</p>
<p></i></p>
<p>In this seminar we will explore some of the aesthetic and sociopolitical debates linked to the term &#8220;Baroque.&#8221; Even though in the case of the Americas, many studies situate the emergence of the Baroque in European settings that later on &#8220;exported&#8221; its form and style to the Indies, we will contemplate connecting the Baroque&#8217;s rhetorical style to 16th century debates about the new territories, and to the role of the colonial experience in the development of aesthetics and politics on the other side of the Atlantic. We will study thinkers who explicitly connect the Baroque with modernity.  The course will be centered on Baroque texts from New Spain (and perhaps Peru), though we will also read texts produced in Spain. In addition, we will read representative texts of the political, religious, and philosophical thinking of the period (Loyola, Descartes, Leibniz) as well as contemporary literary theorists who help us understand the Baroque as either a historical period or a general style (Echeverria, Deleuze).</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?y=5&p_ccn=86373&p_term=FL&p_deptname=Spanish&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&p_course=280&x=46">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>
<div id="footer" class="content" role="contentinfo">

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-376 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2013-fall" id="post-376">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Italian 215: Boccaccio’s Renaissance</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Albert Ascoli </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><i>This course fulfills the Intellectual History requirement for the DE in REMS.  It may also count as an elective.<br />
To fulfill the DE requirement, the course must be taken for 4 credits.</i></p>
<p>A dated and yet not entirely discarded cliché calls Petrarch the “first modern man,” and the pervasive influence of Petrarch on both the growth of Latin Humanism and lyric Petrarchism in the 15<sup>th</sup> and 16<sup>th</sup> centuries is widely acknowledged.  The thesis of this course (and of a conference that will also be held during fall 2013) is that Petrarch’s contemporary, friend and follower, Giovanni Boccaccio, had an influence no less pervasive—indeed perhaps far more so—but far less widely considered by the scholarship.  Boccaccio, to begin with, plays a critical role in the Renaissance reception and diffusion of the works of both Petrarch and their illustrious precursor, Dante, as well as in the repackaging and expansion of the classical literary canon.  Boccaccio’s <i>Decameron</i>, of course, generated a flourishing early modern tradition of proto-novelistic short-story collections (think of Marguerite de Navarre and Cervantes), but also provided substantial material for the nascent dramatic tradition (from Machiavelli’s <i>Mandragola</i> to Shakespeare’s <i>All’s Well</i>).  His biographical collection, <i>Of Famous Women</i>, was an indispensable source and model for the wide-spread debates on the status of women.  His <i>Genealogy of the Gentile Gods </i>was a staple of the Renaissance mythographical tradition.  His geographical treatises continued to make an impact even as the map of the world underwent a remarkable series of changes.  And so on and on.  The aim of this course is not simply to take note of the various ways in which Boccaccio’s <i>oeuvre </i>lived on “in itself” and in its influence throughout European early modernity, but also to reflect on the cultural project and authorial “subject position” that made “Boccaccism” at once ubiquitous and invisible from the 14<sup>th</sup> century to the 17<sup>th</sup>.</p>
<p><b> </b><b>Course requirements:</b> Students are expected to attend and participate regularly.  There will be occasional in-class presentations and some shorter writing assignments.  Students will also be expected to attend and actively participate in the international conference, “A Boccaccian Renaissance?” planned for October 24-26, 2013.  The principal assignment for the course is a research paper of ca. 6000 words (20-25 pages), an advanced draft of which will be presented to the seminar during the final weeks of the semester.  Topics must be closely related to the concerns of the course although they may focus on authors, texts and issues not directly treated in seminar.</p>
<p><b>Prerequisites:</b>  Graduate standing; consent of the instructor.</p>
<p><b>Course Conducted in English</b></p>
<p><b>Reading Knowledge of Italian highly desirable, but not required; reading knowledge of French, Spanish, and/or Latin very useful.</b></p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?y=0&p_term=FL&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&p_course=215&p_dept=Italian&x=0">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-933 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2016-fall" id="post-933">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History of Art 260: Botticelli: The Making of a Renaissance Artist</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Henrike Christiane Lange </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>This graduate seminar opens a wide historiographic panorama on Botticelli’s life and works from his time to the present day. Following the participants’ interests, we will focus with increasing intensity on the nineteenth-century making of Botticelli (Pater, Ruskin, the Pre-Raphaelites), on the early modern sources (from the first anonymous notes to Vasari), and their reading in the late nineteenth century (Aby Warburg’s 1893 dissertation, <em>Sandro Botticellis “Geburt der Venus” und “Frühling”: Eine Untersuchung über die Vorstellungen von der Antike in der italienischen Frührenaissance</em>) to the late twentieth century’s theoretical approaches to Botticelli’s intensely erotic, devastatingly beautiful, and at times likewise devastatingly violent imagery (Georges Didi-Huberman’s 1999 <em>Ouvrir Vénus: Nudité, rêve, cruauté</em>).</p>
<p>We will discuss themes of the body and nature, allegories, Antiquity, nudity, heroes, <em>Madonne</em>, Rome as commemorated in Botticelli’s Sistine Chapel frescoes, Dante as imagined in Botticelli’s illustrations for the Divine Comedy, the Medici and Savonarola as major factors in the social fabric around the artist, his graphic work, his mannerism, and the responses to Botticelli in the twentieth century (from the spheres of advertising to Andy Warhol). With the last chapter, we will enter the current discussions of the innovative exhibit “Botticelli Reimagined” (organised by the V&amp;A and the Gemäldegalerie – Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, on view in London 5 March 2016 – 3 July 2016). This most recent exhibit on Botticelli involves Andy Warhol, Cindy Sherman, and Bill Viola as well as those earlier artistic responses to Botticelli by Edward Burne-Jones, Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Edgar Degas, and René Magritte.</p>
<p>While the course aims at increasing the awareness for the different historiographic lenses one is used to look at early modern artists in general, it is in constant dialogue with the works. Botticelli’s paintings will therefore appear in a likewise reflected sequence of different art historical approaches, from the material study of the conservator’s perspective to iconographical analysis with appropriate biblical and ancient sources, and approaches from theory. At the end of the course, we will have developed a more complex and more complete image of Botticelli’s works on the one hand, and of the long history of writings about these works on the other hand.</p>
<p>The course will be held in English; all required readings are in English. Additional readings in Italian, German, French, and Spanish will be discussed in class according to the participants’ individual levels of reading knowledge in these languages.</p>

				<p><a href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-379 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2013-fall" id="post-379">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Spanish 260 : Cervantes</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ignacio Navarrete </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><i>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</i><i></i></p>
<p>This class is designed to help graduate students develop their own reading and interpretation of <i>Don Quijote</i>. Emphasis will be on close reading of the novel; among the topics to be considered are the relationship between <i>Don Quijote</i> and the origins and development of the modern novel, as well as views on love, beauty, freedom, religion, empire, justice, duty, verisimilitude, poetic theory, and many other topics. In addition to the text of the novel, each week there will be selections from sources, criticism, and theories of the novel. The course is open to students who have not previously read the <i>Quijote</i>; they will be expected to write several interpretative essays. Those who are already familiar with the novel can do more extended reading in the criticism, leading to a research paper.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?y=9&p_term=FL&p_deptname=Spanish&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&p_course=260&x=22">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-992 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2017-spring" id="post-992">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Spanish 280: Christianity and Capitalism</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ivonne del Valle </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the Intellectual History or elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>According to Max Weber the spirit of Protestantism made possible the emergence of capitalism proper. In his recounting, Spain’s imperial/colonial experience could be bracketed as a previous and/or different moment, what Marx termed primitive accumulation. Without negating that the 16<sup>th</sup> and 17<sup>th</sup> centuries in the Americas (one of the central vantage points of the course) could be rightfully considered in such a way, we will study how religion and economy intermingled, clashed, and related to each other in an enterprise in which they were the central, directing forces (evangelization/exploitation of people and resources).</p>
<p>Focusing on Spain’s Catholic version of the economy we will investigate violence and its justification, religious metaphors and ideology, as well as the processes of rationalization and discipline, ordering that accompanied the expansion of Christianity, in order to understand the particular forms the economy took under early modern/colonial Catholicism and the cultural, social forms that accompanied it.</p>

				<p><a href="https://bcsweb.is.berkeley.edu/psc/bcsprd_pub/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.CLASS_SEARCH.GBL?ucFrom=berkeley">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-750 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-fall" id="post-750">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Spanish 280, section 2: Colonial technologies</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ivonne del Valle </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>Recent work of environmental historians has demonstrated how Spanish America underwent drastic changes during the colonial period. From the desertification of 20% of what is now Mexico to the traces of pollution found in the ice caps of the Andes due to mining, it would appear that, since the 16<sup>th</sup> century, the relationship between technology and economic activity had a detrimental impact on the “New World” natural environment which is only now beginning to be studied. By the same token, it could be argued that entire populations underwent equally drastic changes, some of them related to technological and economic enterprises (such as mining), others related to more subtle interventions (religious conversion, the learning of Spanish and alphabetic writing, etc.). If, as in the latter case, new methods (evangelization, training in alphabetic writing, etc.) were devised as means to particular ends (conversion, transformation), we could consider that the whole colonial enterprise became a moment in which technology was potentialized, radicalized.</p>
<p>In this course, we will undertake two tasks:</p>
<ol>
<li>a) A theoretical exploration of what technology is: how it was conceived of at different times, by different cultures and different thinkers (Aristotle, Lucretius, Heidegger, Serres, Nancy, among others), and its “explosion” as a field of interest after World War II, and above all, recently.</li>
<li>b) A reading of pre-Hispanic and colonial sources (mainly from Peru and Mexico; in Spanish) on what colonial technology was and the impact it had on natural environments, urban centers, and the populations that inhabited them.</li>
</ol>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=FL&x=68&p_ccn=86391&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=Spanish&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=8">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="content">
	<div id="courses-sidebar">
		<h2 class="widgettitle">Archive</h2>
<div class="menu-courses-container"><ul id="menu-courses" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1132" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-1132"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2018-spring/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1044" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-1044"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-941" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-941"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2016-fall/">Fall 2016</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-864" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-864"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2016-spring/">Spring 2016</a></li>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-264 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2013-spring" id="post-264">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Law 229.5: Constitutionalism before the Constitution</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Kinch Hoekstra </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p>This course fulfills the elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>Tues 2:10-5, 2240 Piedmont, 3 units, CCN 49655</p>
<p>This is a seminar in the history of political and legal theory. We will explore the idea of fundamental law, illegal laws, mixed government and divided sovereignty, the development of checks and balances, and the very idea of a constitution. We will touch briefly on the Athenian and Roman constitutions, and will read texts by Aquinas, Dante, Francisco Suarez, Johannes Althusius, Edward Coke, Charles I, William Prynne, James Harrington, Locke, and Montesquieu, and documents including Magna Carta, the Petition of Right, and the Answer to the 19 Propositions.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.law.berkeley.edu/php-programs/courses/coursePage.php?cID=10282">http://www.law.berkeley.edu/php-programs/courses/coursePage.php?cID=10282</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

				<p><a href="http://www.law.berkeley.edu/php-programs/courses/coursePage.php?cID=10282">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>
</ul></div></div>
	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-860 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2016-spring" id="post-860">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History of Art 270: Cultural Transfer: Problems and Methods in the Study of Renaissance and Early Modern Visual Cultures (Colonial Latin America and the Trans-Atlantic World)</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Todd Olson </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the Critical Approaches and Methodology requirement for the DE in REMS. It may also count as an elective.<br />
</em></p>
<p>This seminar will examine art historical theories and critical tools concerning the transmission, circulation and translation of images, artifacts, performances and visual technologies. The seminar’s readings and studies will focus on the special case of colonial Latin American, Spanish Empire, and the trans-Atlantic world. In addition to reading the recent literature in this temporal and geographic field (Cummins, Leibsohn, Mundy, Seed among others), the seminar will consider the latent potential of modes of art historical explanation that have addressed the persistence of images and the role of materiality in representation (Semper, Riegl, Warburg, Kubler). Emphasis will be placed on developing transposable models by studying transcultural historical phenomena that have been structured by a variety of legacies including Greco-Roman antiquity, Arabic epistemologies, the representation of Islam (<em>Reconquista</em>), indigenous pictorial survivals, cross-cultural scribal practices and biological metaphor (<em>mestizaje</em>) by different early modern (imperial) constituencies.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=SP&x=0&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=0&p_course=270&p_dept=histart">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-126 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2012-fall" id="post-126">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History 275B: EARLY MODERN EUROPE</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Ethan Shagan </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p>This course fulfills the elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>Fri 2-4, 211 Dwinelle, 4 units, CCN 39714</p>
<p>History 275B is the foundational course in the history of early modern Europe from roughly 1400 to 1800, or from the Renaissance through the French Revolution. The course offers an intensive introduction to major themes and historiographical debates and aims to develops graduate students&#8217; skills in historical criticism. It is intended for graduate students in the history department with EME as their first or second field; other graduate students may take the course with permission of the instructor.</p>

				<p><a href="">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-986 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2017-spring" id="post-986">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History 275B : Early Modern Europe</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Ethan Shagan </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the Intellectual History or elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>History 275 is the foundational course for graduate students in the history of early modern Europe from the Renaissance to the French Revolution. This year, rather than surveying disconnected subjects, I have decided to organize the syllabus around the theme “Forms and Functions of Early Modern Politics.” This is capacious enough to include a wide range of interconnected topics: state formation; empire; gender and power; popular politics; the general crisis of the seventeenth century; political culture; church-state relations; and much else besides. Readings will consist of secondary scholarship covering many different parts of (mostly Western) Europe from the fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries, supplemented by primary sources in political theory from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment.</p>

				<p><a href="https://bcsweb.is.berkeley.edu/psc/bcsprd_pub/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.CLASS_SEARCH.GBL?ucFrom=berkeley">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-929 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2016-fall" id="post-929">

			<h2 class="single-course">	French 245A: Early Modern Studies &#8212; 17th and 18th Century Theater</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Susan Maslan </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>Theater was France’s pre-eminent art form from the seventeenth through the early nineteenth centuries. Theater was also a public, collective social experience as well as a cultural institution often in contention with other institutions—religious and political. We will study some major plays of the 17th and 18th centuries (Corneille, Racine, Moliere, Marivaux, Voltaire, Beaumarchais). We will seek to understand some of the important literary and aesthetic stakes of these works, as well as to investigate the social and political history of the theater (organization of theater troupes, audiences and their social composition, censorship practices, etc.). We will think about the role and the effects of genre (tragedy vs. comedy; the rise of “drame”). We will study contemporary debates about the theater and trace theater’s importance as a crucible for the formation and expression of public opinion.</p>

				<p><a href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-980 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2017-spring" id="post-980">

			<h2 class="single-course">	English 246C: English Renaissance</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor David Marno </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>In this survey, we follow how authors from Francesco Petrarca and Thomas More to John Donne participated in the grand <em>cultural</em> <em>project</em> of the Renaissance, ostensibly defined by the belief that consuming and producing culture would elevate human beings above their natural state. Many of our authors supported the project; some opposed it fervently. But willingly or not, everyone we read during the semester contributed to it, if only by virtue of recording their impressions, thoughts, feelings, and fancies in writing. In addition to the works of Petrarca, Wyatt, Philip and Mary Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, and Donne, among others, we will also explore how scholarly views about the Renaissance as a cultural project have changed and developed from Jacob Burckhardt’s <em>The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy</em> to New Historicism and beyond.</p>

				<p><a href="https://bcsweb.is.berkeley.edu/psc/bcsprd_pub/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.CLASS_SEARCH.GBL?ucFrom=berkeley">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-645 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-spring" id="post-645">

			<h2 class="single-course">	English 203 : Erotic Renaissance</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor James Grantham Turner </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>A sampling of sixteenth-century discourses of sexuality, theories of Eros, artworks and writings about the erotic in art, from major male and female authors in Italy, France and England. The aim is to test the hypothesis of my recent research – that an “erotic revolution” transformed Italian art and art writing – and to explore how far it applies to other literatures. For a brief period, after 1500 and before the Counter-Reformation, arousal could be interpreted as a positive experience that yielded new ways of seeing and producing art, at the center rather than the margins of the culture. Some of the texts we will read are openly libertine or obscenely explicit, others develop the amorous sonnet and the philosophical love-treatise in more elevated language, but all manifest the “corporeal turn” away from strict Petrarchanism and Neoplatonism. Authors include Pietro Aretino, Marsilio Ficino, Antonio Vignali, Baldessare Castiglione, Tullia d’Aragona, Veronica Franca, François Rabelais, Louise Labé, Michel de Montaigne, Pierre de Brantôme, Philip Sidney, Thomas Nashe and John Donne.</p>
<p>The first half of the semester will focus on art and writing in Italy, typified by the range of Aretino’s letters, poems and dialogues – from high aesthetics to (literal) pornography. The emphasis will be on primary texts and images, but to frame the conversation I will also designate passages from my recently completed book manuscript <em>Eros Visible</em>, which I describe as “a broad, synthetic history of this ‘sex-positive’ phase of the Renaissance, when <em>lascivious </em>became a neutral or endearing term, when sculpture was valued for ‘filling every viewer’s mind with libido’ (Aretino) and beauty was discovered in earthly rather than‘celestial’ love. Even more than beauty artists strove for the <em>living </em>quality of the image, ‘awakening’ and reanimating the Classical models they studied, and erotic response was the best guarantee of vitality. In this stimulating moment artists’ discoveries and writers’ ideas fed each other. Patrons and critics who valued ‘profane’ Eros more highly also encouraged sensuous intensity and sexual subject-matter. Recovering libertine art is only one element in this revolution, however. I explore the increasing emphasis on erotic passion in Renaissance art theory, which challenged artists to depict states of intense feeling and to evolve sensuous techniques that ‘melt’ or ‘penetrate’ the viewer likewise. My subject is not so much sex in the explicit sense as Eros in general – the evocation of desire in and for art.”</p>
<p>All texts will be taught in English, with originals in Italian, Latin or French on hand. 203- series courses are designed as exploratory “proseminars” or “readings” and may be taken by specialists and non-specialists, either as a survey (with paper topics on core texts or images from the syllabus) or as a research seminar. <em>You may choose to write two shorter papers (note deadlines below) or one longer paper</em>. Except for paperback editions of the Vignali, Aretino <em>Dialogues</em>, Labé and Nashe texts listed below, ALL course materials will be available in electronic form for download from bCourses, and include high-resolution images of the erotic engraving series <em>I Modi </em>and <em>T</em><em>he Loves of the Gods</em>, together with paintings by Titian, Parmigianino, Bronzino and Michelangelo. To pursue secondary reading, begin with the endnotes of <em>Eros Visible</em>, which can be mined electronically to generate a bibliography of the Italian part; other suggestions will be made once your individual interests become clearer.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=SP&p_ccn=28367&x=42&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=0">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

<li id="menu-item-512" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-512"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2013-fall/">Fall 2013</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-251" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-251"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2013-spring/">Spring 2013</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category current-courses-ancestor current-menu-parent current-courses-parent menu-item-290"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2012-fall/">Fall 2012</a></li>
</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>
</ul></div></div>
	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-115 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2012-fall" id="post-115">

			<h2 class="single-course">	French 245A: FRENCH SOCIETY AND THE OLD REGIME (1600-1800)</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Déborah Blocker </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><strong></strong>This course fulfills the elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>Th 10-1, 4226 Dwinelle, 4 units, CCN 32547</p>
<p>This seminar introduces students to the historiography of early modern French society (1600-1800), by comparing modern historiographical writings on the topic to a variety of literary texts ­ plays, novels, mémoires and social satire ­ from the 17th and 18th centuries, which depict early modern French society or reflect on particular social problems. It asks not only what was French society in the Old Régime, but also how did the very notion of an &#8220;Old Régime&#8221; society come into existence and in what ways is this historiographical construct still important for us today? To answer these questions, the seminar will focus on how modern historiography works to reconstruct France&#8217;s forgone social realities and what role literary productions might have played in the process. Intersections between historiography and fiction will be stressed, as well as the fact that early modern literary representations of social issues have often shaped modern historians&#8217; perceptions of them. The seminar will pay particular attention to how literature&#8217;s growing importance in early modern French society has impacted the way historians, to this day, continue to use such literary productions to historicize pre-Revolutionary France. Historical readings are taken from the French tradition of social history, as it developed out of and around the Annales school (Pierre Goubert, Daniel Roche, Roger Chartier, Robert Descimon, etc.) as well as from the works of their Anglo-Saxon counterparts (William Beik, Nathalie Zemon Davis, Jonathan Dewald, Peter Sahlins, etc). Literary readings include excerpts from a wide variety of early modern French works. Molière&#8217;s Georges Dandin, La Fayette&#8217;s Princesse de Clèves, Marivaux&#8217; Le Paysan Parvenu and Diderot&#8217;s La Religieuse are read in full, along with some relevant literary and historical criticism. A number of theoretical and methodological readings are also discussed (Paul Ricoeur, Jacques Rancière, Christian Jouhaud et alt., etc).</p>
<p>No prior knowledge of early modern French society or literature is needed. This course is taught entirely in English, with readings available both in English and in French.</p>

				<p><a href="">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-1058 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2017-fall" id="post-1058">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Italian Studies 204: From Gramsci to Agamben: Philosophy, Politics and Italian Theory</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Diego Pirillo </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>Is there an Italian Theory? What are its origins and the reasons for its popularity outside of Italy? Why do most of its protagonists, regardless of their philosophical positions, share a tense and troubled relationship with political (and religious) power? The seminar will address these and other questions and introduce students to the most important figures of modern and contemporary Italian thought. Readings will include not only Antonio Gramsci and Giorgio Agamben but a wide selection of classic authors, such as Benedetto Croce, Giovanni Gentile, Norberto Bobbio, Ernesto de Martino, Adriana Cavarero and Antonio Negri. Particular attention will be given to the Italian debate on the ‘political’ (borrowing the concept from Carl Schmitt) and to the relationship between theory and politics that marked Italian philosophy from Fascism to the cold war era until today.</p>
<p>The course is taught in English with readings in English.</p>

				<p><a href="https://bcsweb.is.berkeley.edu/psp/bcsprd/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.CLASS_SEARCH.GBL?ucFrom=CalCentral&ucFromText=My%20Dashboard&ucFromLink=https%3A%2F%2Fcalcentral.berkeley.edu%2Fdashboard">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

<div id="header" class="content courses">
		<h1><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/">Renaissance &amp; Early Modern Studies</a></h1>
		<div class="description"></div>
</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-889 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2016-spring" id="post-889">

			<h2 class="single-course">	English 203: Graduate Readings: Edmund Spenser</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor David Landreth </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>Sidney wrote that a poet&#8217;s task was to &#8220;grow in effect another nature.&#8221; No poet in English has fulfilled that charge more luxuriantly than Spenser. The plan of the semester will be to roam around in the leisurely, delight-filled capaciousness of <em>The Faerie Queene</em>, with the aim that each of us find herself at home somewhere in this alienated version of our own world. The tension between delight and didacticism, leisure and urgency, is central to any such accommodation; I&#8217;m also interested in questions of materiality and of landscape in the fiction, and I expect our inquiries will be shaped by your preoccupations as well. We&#8217;ll take some detours into the shorter poems along the way, and we will try too to reckon with the genocidal despair by which Spenser articulates the project of making a home in the alien terrain of Ireland.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_instr=landreth&p_term=SP&x=71&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=4&p_course=203&p_dept=english">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-106 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2012-fall" id="post-106">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History of Art 260: Graduate Seminar (Renaissance): Jusepe de Ribera (1591-1652)</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Todd Olson </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><strong></strong>This course fulfills the elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>Th 2-5, 308 B Doe Library, 4 units, CCN 05070</p>
<p>The Spanish born artist, who was active in Rome and Naples during the first half of the seventeenth-century, has left a series of works that are remarkable for their repetitiveness. Thumbnail photos of his oil paintings in catalogue raisonées betray obsessive repetition. This seminar will consider how figurative iteration, reversibility and material degradation in Ribera’s etchings provided an experimental practice. The seminar will also consider the late work of Caravaggio in Naples, Sicily and Malta, Ribera’s representation of torture and martyrdom, his graphic procedures, and the politics of representation in viceregal Naples.</p>

				<p><a href="">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-127 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2012-fall" id="post-127">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History 280B: HETERODOXY, ORTHODOXY, AND EARLY MODERN RELIGION</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Jonathan Sheehan </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p>This course fulfills the elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>Wed 3-6, 2303 Dwinelle, 4 units, CCN 39759</p>
<p>Christianity has always oriented itself toward, and put an enormous premium on, an organizing principle of orthodoxy. In the early modern period, however, orthodoxy exploded into competing factions. Multiple orthodoxies emerged, and in their wake, a host of heterodoxies and heresies. These dynamics put enormous pressure on normative Christianity, and were powerfully generative of new forms of religious, political, and cultural life. This course will treat this period of dynamic diversification, roughly spanning 1450-1700, as a laboratory for studying the history and historiography of modern religion.</p>
<p>Problems and topics that we will explore will include: the contested nature of orthodoxy; the problem of religious innovation; the nature of theology as an intellectual and cultural practice; the issues of ritual and ceremony in religious life; idolatry and iconoclasm as problems of religious and social order; new genres of religious writing from martyrology to heresiology; the question of atheism as both historical and historiographical subject; the discourse of toleration; and finally, most generally, the issue of secularism and secularization in the wake of European religious conflict.</p>

				<p><a href="">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-810 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-fall" id="post-810">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Political Science 212B: History of Political Thought: Early Modern (Renaissance to French Revolution)</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Kinch Hoekstra </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>In this iteration of the course in Renaissance and Early Modern Political Thought, we will focus on a close reading of <em>The Elements of Law </em>(1640) by Thomas Hobbes.  This work has a similar range to that of Hobbes&#8217;s 1651 <em>Leviathan</em>, though with much less attention to theological and ecclesiastical matters.  The earlier weeks of the course will be devoted to a consideration of background materials that are also of intrinsic interest, including Jean Bodin&#8217;s <em>Six Books of the Republic</em>.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=FL&x=0&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=0&p_course=212b&p_dept=PS">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-521 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2014-spring" id="post-521">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Political Science 212B: History of Political Thought: Topics in Renaissance and Early Modern Thought</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Shannon Stimson </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p>This course fulfills the Intellectual History requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>The purpose of the seminar is to examine selected writings of crucial thinkers in the history of Renaissance and Early Modern Political Thought (Erasmus, Machiavelli, Bacon, Shakespeare, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Hume and Marx). Secondary writings accompanying each thinker will assist us in considering some of the contextual and interpretive issues of relevance to these thinkers, and in considering such problems as: counsel, authority, sovereignty, tyranny, subjection, oaths, obedience, religious toleration, forms of political participation, sociability and civil government, justice, equality, and revolution.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=SP&p_ccn=72015&x=44&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=4">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-1045 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2017-fall" id="post-1045">

			<h2 class="single-course">	French 201: History of the French Language</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Mairi McLaughlin </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>This course covers the history of the French language from its Latin roots through to contemporary usage. Both internal and external history will be considered so that students acquire a firm grounding in the linguistic evolution of the language, coupled with an understanding of its development in relation to a range of social and cultural phenomena. The course will be structured around our analysis of the wide range of texts from different genres presented by Ayres-Bennett (1996) and which date from 842 CE to the present day. We will use the relatively new historical sociolinguistic approach to try to capture what Anthony Lodge (2009) has called “une image multidimensionnelle de la langue du passé”.</p>

				<p><a href="https://bcsweb.is.berkeley.edu/psp/bcsprd/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.CLASS_SEARCH.GBL?ucFrom=CalCentral&ucFromText=My%20Dashboard&ucFromLink=https%3A%2F%2Fcalcentral.berkeley.edu%2Fdashboard">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>
<div id="footer" class="content" role="contentinfo">
<div class="footernav">
	<ul>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-745 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-fall" id="post-745">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History of Art 262: Human Nature: Between Medieval and Modern</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: ProfessorsBeate Fricke and Elizabeth Honig </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>What is Mankind? How are we placed in the cosmos; what constitutes the fundamental nature of our being; and in what ways can we be elevated, inspired, socialized, and corrupted? Our ways of answering these questions are said to have undergone a fundamental shift with the advent of renaissance humanism. This course investigates the nature and extent of that shift, and asks which areas of thinking about mankind were more, and less, altered at the dawn of the modern period. Topics will include the ways in which the story of Creation was understood, the location of mankind in the universe, how law and society are formed by and set boundaries upon the fundamental nature of man, and the importance (and limits) of education. We will think about human pleasures (sinful or playful), the definition of human creativity, and how the human body and its failings are understood. We will end with death, war, and the apocalypse.</p>
<p>Our particular focus will be on the ways in which the nature of mankind was visualized by European artists, from anonymous illuminators to Dürer, Holbein, Bosch and Bruegel, Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo. Much of our reading will be from primary sources, including Paracelsus, Bartholomaeus Anglicus, Pico della Mirandola, Machiavelli, Thomas More, Erasmus, and Montaigne, as well as writing by artists.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=FL&x=71&p_ccn=05223&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=Art%2c+History+of&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=11">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

<li id="menu-item-251" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-251"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2013-spring/">Spring 2013</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-290"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2012-fall/">Fall 2012</a></li>
</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>
</ul></div></div>
	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-982 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2017-spring" id="post-982">

			<h2 class="single-course">	English 250 : Idols and Ideology</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor Vicki Kahn </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the Intellectual History or elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>The history of Western literary theory is often told in terms of the concept of mimesis. But there is another, equally powerful, anti-mimetic strand to this history, and that is the critique of mimesis as a form of idolatry. In this course, we will explore this critique from the prohibition against images in the Hebrew bible up through modern attacks on mimesis as inherently ideological. Our main literary texts in the first half of the semester will be taken from Reformation England, when there was a fierce debate about the harmful power of images and the necessity of iconoclasm. We will focus on works by Calvin, Luther, Marlowe, Bacon, Shakespeare, and Milton. In the second half of the semester, we will discuss the afterlife of iconoclasm in Marx, Freud, Althusser, Zizek, Adorno, Terry Eagleton, and Isobel Armstrong. Students whose interests lie primarily in national literatures other than English are welcome, and may write their final papers on primary texts and literatures not discussed in class, though they must engage the theoretical texts assigned for the seminar.</p>

				<p><a href="https://bcsweb.is.berkeley.edu/psc/bcsprd_pub/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.CLASS_SEARCH.GBL?ucFrom=berkeley">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>
</ul></div></div>
	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-935 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2016-fall" id="post-935">

			<h2 class="single-course">	History of Art 290 : Insiders and Outsiders in the Age of Pieter Bruegel</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professors Elizabeth Honig  </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills an elective requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>This seminar considers how group identification was formed, and what defined exclusion from those groups, in northern Europe of the early- to mid-16<sup>th</sup> century.  We will focus in particular on two questions integral to a renaissance conception of social belonging: the normative body and physical othering (deportment, disability, the racially other), and dwelling vs. a state of placelessness (vagrants, beggars, itinerant artists, other sorts of travelers).  We will put pressure on the paintings of Flemish painter Pieter Bruegel as the testimony of an artist thinking deeply about what it meant to belong, or not, in renaissance Europe, and we will read English and Flemish primary texts and documents about the disabled, vagrants, and soldiers; travel literature and &#8216;underworld&#8217; texts; and modern theories of community, dwelling, embodiment and disability. No foreign language reading will be necessary.</p>
<p>This is a graduate/undergraduate seminar. Permission of the instructor is required; if possible, please contact me at <a href="mailto:elizahonig@yahoo.com">elizahonig@yahoo.com</a> by mid-August as there will be assigned readings for the first meeting. This class may be taken for 2 units (without research component) or for 4.</p>

				<p><a href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

<div class="page">

<div id="header" class="content courses">
		<h1><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/">Renaissance &amp; Early Modern Studies</a></h1>
		<div class="description"></div>
</div>
<div id="nav" class="content" role="navigation">
		<div class="menu-main-navigation-courses-container"><ul id="menu-main-navigation-courses" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1133" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-1133"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2018-spring/">Courses</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-657" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-657"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2014-fall/">Fall 2014</a></li>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-114 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2012-fall" id="post-114">

			<h2 class="single-course">	Comparative Literature 215: INTRODUCTION TO RENAISSANCE HUMANISM</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Victoria Kahn </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p>This course fulfills the Intellectual History requirement for the DE in REMS.</p>
<p>Wed 2-5, 225 Dwinelle, 4 units, CCN 17356</p>
<p>An introduction to Renaissance humanism, focusing on the work of Petrarch, Bruni, Salutati, Valla, Machiavelli, Castiglione, Erasmus, More, Ascham, Elyot, Lipsius, and Shakespeare. In addition, we will read some of the classics of Renaissance scholarship (Burckhardt, Kristeller, Baron, Garin, Trinkaus, Greenblatt, Cave and Greene), as well as more recent work in the field. Topics will include Renaissance theories of imitation and literary production, the revival of classical rhetoric, humanist pedagogical practices, the civic and political function of rhetoric, the transformation of political theory, the relationship between Christianity and classical culture. We will also discuss the critique of humanism both in the early modern period and in modern evaluations of Renaissance humanist pedagogy by Grafton and Jardine, Halpern, Crane, Dolven and others. Reading knowledge of Italian or Latin is particularly useful but not required.</p>

				<p><a href="">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>

</ul></div><div class="menu-courses-of-interest-container"><ul id="menu-courses-of-interest" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-286" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-286"><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/courses-category/courses-of-interest/">Courses of Interest</a></li>

	<div class="courses-listing">
			<div class="post-838 courses type-courses status-publish hentry courses-category-2015-fall" id="post-838">

			<h2 class="single-course">	English 250, section 4: John Donne and T.S. Eliot: Lyric Poetry and Society</h2>
<p><i>Instructor: Professor David Marno </i></p>
			<div class="entry">
				<p><em>This course fulfills the Intellectual History requirement for the DE in REMS.</em></p>
<p>“Permit me to repeat,” Adorno writes in his celebrated essay on lyric poetry’s relationship to its context, “that we are concerned not with the poet as a private person, not with his psychology or his so-called social perspective, but with the poem as a philosophical sundial telling the time of history.” In this course, we read the poetries of John Donne and T. S. Eliot to see how (or indeed whether) they tell the time of history. To raise the stakes of this exercise, we will focus on Donne’s <em>Holy Sonnets</em> and Eliot’s <em>Four Quartets</em>, ie. poems that share an investment in religion but were written under markedly different circumstances. How does a religious poem that is the product of a religious culture differ from a religious poem written in a predominantly secular society? How do poems express, resist, or ignore their immediate contexts? How do they transpose themselves in other, real of fictional contexts? And what critical tools best enable us to articulate and answer such questions? In addition to spending ample time on the poems, we will read Eliot on early modern poetry, modern critics on Donne and Eliot, and representative critical essays on lyric poetry.</p>

				<p><a href="http://osoc.berkeley.edu/OSOC/osoc?p_term=FL&x=51&p_ccn=28771&p_classif=--+Choose+a+Course+Classification+--&p_deptname=--+Choose+a+Department+Name+--&p_presuf=--+Choose+a+Course+Prefix%2fSuffix+--&y=10">Section times and locations in the Schedule of Classes</a></p>
				
		</div>
</div>

</div>
